marketNews.title: Government Officially Changes Minerba Royalty Rates
marketNews.content:
The Government officially raised royalty rates for a number of mineral commodities – such as nickel, copper, and gold – through Government Regulation No. 19/2025. In addition, the government also adjusted royalties for coal producers operating under a Special Mining Business License (IUPK) through Government Regulation No. 18/2025.

Both regulations are largely the same as the proposal submitted by the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (ESDM) in early March 2025 – which we previously summarized in Stockbit Commentary – where most mineral commodities receive higher royalty rates, while coal producers with IUPK licences see lower rates.

However, the final increase in royalty rates for ferronickel and nickel matte is lower than the earlier proposal. Previously, the Ministry of ESDM proposed ferronickel royalties of 5-7 percent and nickel matte royalties of 4.5-6.5 percent. In the final regulation, ferronickel royalties range from 4-6 percent, while nickel matte royalties are about 3.5-5.5 percent.

There is still no information regarding royalty taxes for coal issuers operating under the Coal Mining Contract Agreement (PKP2B) and regular IUP.

Key Takeaway

We assess that the change in royalty rates could put pressure on the performance of mineral producers such as Vale Indonesia (INCO), Trimegah Bangun Persada (NCKL), Aneka Tambang (ANTM), Bumi Resources Minerals (BRMS), and Amman Mineral Internasional (AMMN). Conversely, the royalty change could improve the performance of coal producers with IUPK contracts – such as Adaro Andalan Indonesia (AADI), Bumi Resources (BUMI), and Indika Energy (INDY). For illustration, the Coal Benchmark Price (HBA) in March 2025 was at USD 128 per ton, so the royalty rate for the three issuers could fall from 28 percent to 19 percent.

In a previous Stockbit Commentary we attempted to calculate the potential impact of the royalty change on net profit for AADI, BUMI, and INDY. Based on our analysis, BUMI would be the most benefited issuer with a potential net profit increase in 2025 of +142 percent year-on-year, followed by INDY (+126 percent YoY) and AADI (+21.9 percent YoY), assuming a main assumption of the average Newcastle coal price at USD 110 per ton.

This article was previously published in Stockbit Commentary on Wednesday (16 April) morning.

*On Tuesday (15 April), Stockbit Snips reported in a table that Mitsubishi recorded sales of 5,769 units (-32 percent YoY, -34 percent MoM) in March 2025 and 21,692 units (-16 percent YoY) over 3M25. The information was incorrect because it did not include Mitsubishi Fuso sales. The correct information is that total Mitsubishi (Motors + Fuso) sales were 7,373 units (-13 percent YoY, -16 percent MoM) in March 2025, making 3M25 sales 23,296 units (-9.4 percent YoY). This error has been corrected on the Stockbit Snips website.

marketNews.title: Other Hot Topics
marketNews.content:
1. US President Donald Trump again asked the Chinese government to start negotiations to resolve the escalating trade war. In response, a spokesperson for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Lin Jian, said that if the US truly wants to solve the problem through dialogue and negotiation, the US must stop using maximum pressure and "stop threats and blackmail."

2. The National Bureau of Statistics of China reported that China's economic growth reached +5.4 percent year-on-year in 1Q25 (versus +5.4 percent YoY in 4Q24), beating the consensus expectation of +5.1 percent YoY and marking the strongest annual growth since 3Q23. Meanwhile, the unemployment rate in March 2025 fell to 5.2 percent (versus 5.4 percent in February 2025), better than the consensus expectation of 5.3 percent. In other data, retail sales in China grew +5.9 percent YoY in March 2025 (versus +4.0 percent YoY in the first two months of 2025), surpassing the consensus expectation of +4.2 percent YoY.

3. Bank Indonesia estimated that Indonesian retail sales grew +0.5 percent YoY and +8.3 percent month-on-month in March 2025. Retail sales in February 2025 were recorded at +2.0 percent YoY and +3.3 percent MoM (versus +0.5 percent YoY and -4.7 percent MoM in January 2024), beating the Bank Indonesia forecast of -0.5 percent YoY and +0.8 percent MoM.

4. Bank Indonesia reported that the Indonesian Consumer Confidence Index fell to 121.1 in March 2025 (versus 126.4 in February 2025), marking a decline for the third consecutive month although it remained in an optimistic range. The decline was driven by lower scores across all sub-indices.

5. Indonesia's Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources, Bahlil Lahadalia, said on Tuesday (15 April) that the Indonesian government proposes to increase imports of oil and LPG from the United States by about USD 10 billion as part of a negotiation proposal to avoid a 32 percent US tariff. In 2024, the United States contributed about 57 percent of total Indonesian LPG imports, which amount to 217,000 barrels per day, and supplied about 4.2 percent of total Indonesian oil imports, which amount to 306,000 barrels per day.

6. Shareholders of Japfa Ltd. (SGX: UD2) on Tuesday accepted a go-private plan, with an expected delisting date from the Singapore exchange on 3 June 2025. Japfa Ltd. is the controlling shareholder of Japfa Comfeed Indonesia (JPFA).

7. Ecocare Indo Pacific (HYGN) plans to conduct a share buyback with a funding allocation of up to IDR 5 billion from 15 April to 15 July 2025, although the company does not disclose the maximum number of shares to be repurchased. This plan does not require shareholder meeting approval, following a relaxation granted by OJK to support market stability.

8. The controlling shareholder of Hillcon (HILL), PT Hillcon Equity Management, sold 10 million HILL shares at IDR 320 per share on 11 April 2025. The total transaction value was IDR 3.2 billion. After the transaction, PT Hillcon Equity Management's ownership in HILL fell from 57.54 percent to 57.47 percent.

tickerNews.title: AADI plans share buyback up to IDR 4 trillion
tickerNews.content: Adaro Andalan Indonesia (AADI) plans to conduct a share buyback with a funding allocation of up to IDR 4 trillion within a 12-month period starting 23 May 2025, although the company does not disclose the maximum number of shares to be repurchased. This plan will be discussed at the Extraordinary General Meeting of Shareholders on 22 May 2025.

tickerNews.title: ASII reports decline in March 2025 vehicle wholesales
tickerNews.content: Astra International (ASII) recorded wholesale vehicle sales of 37,735 units in March 2025 (-6.5 percent YoY, -2.1 percent MoM), worse than the industry average (-5.1 percent YoY, -2.0 percent MoM), causing ASII's market share to fall to 53.2 percent in March 2025 (vs. March 2024: 54 percent, February 2025: 53.3 percent). ASII's March 2025 wholesale sales were supported by Toyota + Lexus sales of 22,658 units (+5.8 percent YoY, -7.5 percent MoM), while Daihatsu sales fell year-on-year to 13,057 units (-21 percent YoY, +9.2 percent MoM). Cumulatively, ASII's 1Q25 wholesale sales dropped to 110,812 units (-7.3 percent YoY), with market share decreasing to 54 percent (vs. 1Q24: 55.6 percent, 2M25: 54.4 percent).

tickerNews.title: Barito Renewables Energy secures US$139.5 million credit facility
tickerNews.content: Barito Renewables Energy (BREN) signed a credit facility agreement for up to US$139.5 million from SMBC and DBS Bank Ltd. The facility is intended to finance the expansion of the Wayang Windu project through retrofitting PLTP unit 1 and unit 2 with an additional capacity of 18.4 MW and the construction of PLTP unit 3 with 30 MW.

tickerNews.title: Indocement Tunggal Prakarsa sees 17 percent YoY sales decline in March 2025
tickerNews.content: Indocement Tunggal Prakarsa (INTP) recorded a 17 percent year-on-year decline in cement sales volume in March 2025, but its market share rose to 30.7 percent (vs. February 2025: 28.6 percent, March 2024: 28.8 percent) as industry-wide sales fell deeper (-22 percent YoY). Consequently, INTP's 1Q25 sales volume fell 5.9 percent YoY, outperforming the industry decline of 7.8 percent YoY. The March 2025 sales drop was mainly due to fewer working days caused by the shift of the Idulfitri holiday. By segment, bagged cement sales and bulk cement sales each fell 13 percent YoY and 25 percent YoY respectively in March 2025.

tickerNews.title: SMGR announces share buyback and real-estate expansion plans
tickerNews.content: Semen Indonesia (SMGR) announced that a share buyback with a funding allocation of up to IDR 300 billion will take place from 24 May 2025 to 23 May 2026, although the company does not disclose the maximum number of shares to be repurchased. SMGR also plans to expand its own or leased real-estate business, large-scale tile, brick, tile and similar product trading, as well as cement-based construction material manufacturing. Both plans will be discussed at the General Meeting of Shareholders on 23 May 2025.

tickerNews.title: CYBR controlling shareholder purchases ~16 million shares
tickerNews.content: Patrick Rudolf Dannacher, controlling shareholder and Chief Commissioner of ITSEC Asia, bought approximately 16 million shares of Cyberindo (CYBR) at an average price of IDR 725 per share between 18 March and 14 April 2025. The total transaction value was about IDR 11.6 billion. After the transaction, Dannacher's ownership in CYBR increased from 0.462 percent to 0.698 percent.

tickerNews.title: Advance Opportunities Fund sells ~33.5 million NINE shares
tickerNews.content: Advance Opportunities Fund, a shareholder of Techno9 Indonesia (NINE), sold approximately 33.5 million NINE shares at an average price of IDR 139 per share on 14-15 April 2025. The total transaction value was about IDR 4.7 billion. After the transaction, the fund's ownership in NINE fell from 16.35 percent to 14.79 percent.

tickerNews.title: Christopher Sumasto Tjia purchases ~11.4 million NICL shares
tickerNews.content: Christopher Sumasto Tjia, controlling shareholder of PAM Mineral, bought approximately 11.4 million shares of Nickel Indonesia (NICL) at an average price of IDR 336 per share between 10 and 15 April 2025. The total transaction value was about IDR 3.8 billion. After the transaction, Tjia's direct ownership in NICL increased from 0.039 percent to 0.147 percent.

tickerNews.title: Samico Capital plans mandatory tender offer for KLIN
tickerNews.content: PT Samico Capital Utama Mulia, the new controlling shareholder of Klinko Karya Imaji (KLIN), plans to conduct a mandatory tender offer for up to 267.5 million shares (20.46 percent of KLIN) between 17 April and 16 May 2025. The tender offer price is IDR 169 per share, potentially valuing the transaction at IDR 45.2 billion. Previously, Samico Capital acquired 60 percent of KLIN shares at IDR 31 per share in February 2025.

tickerNews.title: TPIA and Phoenix Power B.V. deposit USD 185 million into PT Chandra Daya Investasi
tickerNews.content: On Tuesday (15 April), Stockbit Snips reported that the total capital contribution made by Chandra Asri Pacific (TPIA) and Phoenix Power B.V. to PT Chandra Daya Investasi Tbk was IDR 1.75 trillion, consisting of IDR 850 billion from TPIA and IDR 900 billion from Phoenix Power B.V. This information was incorrect. The correct information is that TPIA and Phoenix Power B.V. deposited USD 185 million (approximately IDR 2.96 trillion) into PT Chandra Daya Investasi Tbk, consisting of USD 90 million (approximately IDR 1.44 trillion) from TPIA and USD 95 million (approximately IDR 1.52 trillion) from Phoenix Power B.V. The error has been corrected on the Stockbit Snips website.
